title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct calculation of the standard reduction potential.

E rxn o =  E N O 3 − o −  E C u 2+ o =  E N O 3 − o − 0.34 V = 0.62 V  ⇒  E N O 3 − o = 0.62 V + 0.34 V = 0.96 V
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct calculation of the standard reduction potential.

E rxn o =  E N O 3 − o −  E C u 2+ o =  E N O 3 − o − 0.34 V = 0.62 V  ⇒  E N O 3 − o = 0.62 V + 0.34 V = 0.96 V

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct calculation of the standard reduction potential.

E rxn o =  E N O 3 − o −  E C u 2+ o =  E N O 3 − o − 0.34 V = 0.62 V  ⇒  E N O 3 − o = 0.62 V + 0.34 V = 0.96 V

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct value of n, the number of moles of electrons

1 point is earned for calculating the correct value of ΔG°, with correct sign and consistent units.

ΔG° = −nℱE° = −(6)(96,500 C mol−1)(0.62 V)

= − 360,000 J mol−1 = − 360 kJ mol−1

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct answer with a justification that is based on the gaseous state of one of the products.

ΔS° > 0. Even though there is a loss of 7 moles of ions in solution, the value of ΔS° for the overall reaction will be greater than zero because two moles of NO gas will be produced (there are no gaseous reactants).

title: Part D (i)
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

Comparing experiments 1 and 3, the tripling of the initial concentration of NO while the initial concentration of oxygen remained constant at 0.0300 mol L−1 resulted in a nine-fold increase in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 9 = 32, the reaction is second order with respect to NO.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

Comparing experiments 1 and 3, the tripling of the initial concentration of NO while the initial concentration of oxygen remained constant at 0.0300 mol L−1 resulted in a nine-fold increase in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 9 = 32, the reaction is second order with respect to NO.

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

Comparing experiments 1 and 3, the tripling of the initial concentration of NO while the initial concentration of oxygen remained constant at 0.0300 mol L−1 resulted in a nine-fold increase in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 9 = 32, the reaction is second order with respect to NO.

title: Part D (ii)
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

Comparing experiments 1 and 2, the tripling of the initial concentration of O2 while the initial concentration of NO remained constant at 0.0200 mol L−1 resulted in a tripling in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 3 = 31, the reaction is first order with respect to O2.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

Comparing experiments 1 and 2, the tripling of the initial concentration of O2 while the initial concentration of NO remained constant at 0.0200 mol L−1 resulted in a tripling in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 3 = 31, the reaction is first order with respect to O2.

The student response earns one of the following points:

Comparing experiments 1 and 2, the tripling of the initial concentration of O2 while the initial concentration of NO remained constant at 0.0200 mol L−1 resulted in a tripling in the initial rate of formation of NO2. Since 3 = 31, the reaction is first order with respect to O2.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct expression for the rate law.

rate = k[NO]2[O2]
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct expression for the rate law.

rate = k[NO]2[O2]

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for the correct expression for the rate law.

rate = k[NO]2[O2]

title: Part F
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for calculating the correct value of the rate constant.

1 point is earned for including the correct units

Because the coefficient for NO2 in the balanced equation is 2, the rate of the reaction is defined as 1/2 the rate of the appearance of NO2.

From part (e) above, k = reaction rate [NO] 2 [O 2 ]

 =  ( 1 2 )( rate of formation of  NO 2 ) [NO] 2 [O 2 ]

Substituting data from experiment 1,

 k=  ( 1 2 )( 8.52× 10 −2  mol  L -2 s -1 ) [0.0200  mol L -1 ] 2 [0.0300 mol  L -1 ]

= 3.55 × 103 L2 mol−2s−1

Note: a rate constant value of 7.10 × 103 L2 mol−2s−1 earns the point if the rate of reaction is assumed to be the same as the rate of formation of NO2.
